awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Action-Minimizing Paths in the Space of Probability Measures
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves the study of mathematics underlying systems of equations that model fluid flow.  Applications of such equations include the motion of plasma in blood flow, oil moving through pipelines, and the formation of gaseous planets such as Jupiter and Saturn. The aim of the research is to develop methods that can be used to establish the global existence of solutions to systems of nonlinear partial differential equations that assert the conservation of mass and momentum in a variety of physical phenomena.  In addition to involving students in the research, the investigator will pilot a "bridge to PhD" program intended to increase the number of women and minorities earning PhD degrees in mathematics at the University of Pennsylvania. The investigator will also work with educators at Philadelphia's Workshop School to introduce mathematical modeling into their curriculum and to train teams of students to compete in the annual Moody's Mega Math Challenge contest for high school juniors and seniors organized by the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics. 

The focus of the proposed research is based on the generalized Euler-Poisson equations, a system of partial differential equations used to study the behavior of materials modeled as continuous masses. These equations arise as critical points of an action in the space of probability measures; the project will investigate sufficient and necessary conditions for minimizers of this action to exist. Moreover, the investigator aims is to lay a foundation for a theory of Lagrangian mechanics, calculus of variations, and control theory in the space of probability measures. To this end, he will employ methods from fluid mechanics, optimal transport, functional inequalities, and evolution equations. In collaboration with the University of Pennsylvania's Center for Teaching and Learning, the investigator will organize an interactive seminar based on these topics as a way recruit and train undergraduates to do research. The educational and outreach efforts proposed in this project will enable the investigator to motivate students at all levels from diverse backgrounds to use mathematics in tackling some of our most pressing scientific challenges.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania

por.por_cntn:
This project accomplished three initiatives at the University of Pennsylvania. It helped fund a bridge program in the mathematics department, it saw the creation of a new course on undergraduate research for math majors, and it assisted in a number of advances in the field of partial differential equations. 

The first major outcome of the project was Bridge to PhD. This was a master's program in the mathematics department which aimed to increase the number of PhDs awarded to members of groups that are traditionally underrepresented. This program was different than conventional master's programs as students were fully funded and prepared for entry into a PhD program.  

There were nine students who enrolled in the bridge program over the past five years. Seven students graduated and one is currently enrolled. Of the seven students who graduated, five enrolled in PhD programs in mathematics at research-one programs.  At the conclusion of the project, the mathematics department transitioned this program into a fellowship which feeds directly into its own PhD program.   

A second major outcome of the project was the creation of Math 290, a course in undergraduate research.  In this course, students do a thorough study of a topic of current interest in mathematics. They focus on a single topic for the semester, give a talk for the class, and write term paper. Both the talk and the paper are subject to review, and students are taught how to improve their communications skills.   

The project also involved mathematical research. The PI discovered a condition on solutions of the pressureless-Euler equations in one spatial dimension, called the "quantitative sticky particle property", that clarifies why these equations can be solved for given initial conditions.  In joint work, the PI also provided a qualitative discretion of extremal functions to a fundamental functional inequality known as Morrey's inequality.  In addition, the PI collaborated on work involving optimal vaccination rates for compartmental models, regularity of doubly nonlinear flows, and approximations of equilibria in game theory. 

 


Last Modified: 08/13/2022
Modified by: Ryan C Hynd
